Calculate your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) in calories

Bulking Diet:
Calories: TDEE + 500 calories
Protein: 1+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Cutting Diet:
Calories: TDEE - 500 calories
Protein: 1.5+ grams per lb. bodyweight

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

Eggs, legumes (beans, peas, chickpeas), milk, some type of meat (cheapest would be tuna I suppose), tofu isn't massively expensive either. Frozen leafy greens and broccoli.

As a list ordering proteins from cheapest, highest quality to more expensive or lower quality it would be:
>eggs
>milk
>tuna (not higher due to heavy metals)
>legumes (incomplete alone but cheap and healthy to add to meals)
>frozen meats (very expensive right now)
>peanut butter (relatively inexpensive per serving, but higher in fat than protein)
>frozen green vegetables (cheap and has protein, but not very dense)

Always go with cheap whole foods. Minimally processed.

Right, let me say this really quickly.
I'm in my 40s, I've had long hair since I was 16.
I still look at myself in the mirror and think "Fuck Yeah" I love how I look.
BUT
There are two sorts of women out there.
Women who Like long hair on a man.
Women who Dislike long hair on a man.

For the women who Like long hair, you having short hair isn't a deal breaker, if they're talking with a nice looking short haired guy, they don't get turned off by the lack of long hair, it's just a Nice To Have.

For the women who Dislike long hair, it's likely that they HATE long hair on a man. Instant turn off. Even when they're stroking it at a party and saying "wow your hair is so great" what they often mean is "I wish my hair was this good, but I put a load of shitty dye in it and got a perm and then straightened it again and then used a curling iron on it, and they bleached it so I could dye it"
AND that's if you've got Good Long Hair.

My advice to a young man, thinking about his hairstyle's attractiveness to women, short, fashionable, brushed and combed, no oil, gel or goopy products. If current fashion seem to be heading for longer hair style, never go longer than collar length.

Shorter hair is more practical, washes faster, drys faster, doesn't get in the way. If you're thinking about women liking long hair... some might, but they'll be happy with short hair.

If you want long hair because "Fuck Yeah, I'm going for insane viking wizard aesthetic" or something... and you look in the mirror and love how you look, then do that for yourself.

Even if I can't contain the snail I would do it, but only if I got to know the snail's exact starting location.
Snails crawl at 3 inches per minute. That's 180 inches per hour == 15 feet per hour if they don't stop to rest or eat. That's 0.00284090909 (repeating) miles per hour.
In an entire YEAR it could travel only 3.545454 (repeating) miles.
If I live to 100 (another 72 years) it would only travel 255.27 miles in that time, assuming it moves in a straight line. I could just move a small east coast state over and I'd never have to worry about seeing it.

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>>69249801
In all honesty being "satiated" for 4 hours isn't really being satiated at all. You're basically eating at regular intervals if you're eating every 4-6 hours. Eating once or twice a day while feeling full in between is entirely possible. While I agree with the protein poster I'd also like to add that you can train your ghrelin (hunger hormone) production. Your body adapts pretty quickly based on your eating habits so if you eat three times a day you'll feel hungry each day around those times. If you eat once a day you'll feel hungry around the time you usually eat. Your body and mind can easily adapt to eating less often and it is sustainable while trying to maintain.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69240947
>even thin and fit people like my relatives seem worried
Well there's a couple things at play here. If you have lost a lot of weight rapidly they may be concerned because they've been told that it takes a long time to lose weight healthily. There is also the subconscious aspect of the pecking order. Whether people admit it or not, it does exist. By losing weight you've now changed your status. This will make persons who are insecure in their position worry that you losing weight will change the order of the system. You are likely the "fat relative" that people can use as a way to make them feel better about themselves. If you are no longer the "fat person" it affects their shitty coping mechanism and makes them uncomfortable.

You should definitely ignore anyone who questions your progress. Anyone who is happy for you will congratulate you or ask what you're doing. 90% of the time "concern" of this type is not warranted and is just a socially acceptable way to tell you that you need to stay in your lane. They do not care about you, they care about their own weirdo problems that are coming up for them when they see how you've changed.

Ignore these people anon, and keep reaching for your goal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: So a Google search leads me to believe these will have a similar effect as regular magic mushrooms. Figure out what the recommended dosage is for the strain your going to pick up is, first and foremost. Psychedelic mushrooms are usually not rough in my experience but I've always been recommended to be in a good mindset when you take them, as your mental state can alter the effects(happy drunk vs sad drunk). Take a recommended dose, especially to start off with. I don't recommend for your first time mixing it with any other mind altering effects( alcohol or marijuana). Have a safe area to be in since you may not be in your right mind most likely. I would recommend having an at least mostly sober person with you or to do this as a group activity with a babysitter. Having another person with you to make sure you are okay and that you don't do something dumb, or if you have issues with freaking out can be a life saver. Make sure you have lots of interesting things to see, most hallucinogenic effects at a good beginner dosage are movements and warping of spaces like breathing walls and fuzzy lights, paired with a euphoric high. It's fun.

>>69253565
How about you start by using a calorie/macro tracking app like myfitnesspal? Get at LEAST 0.8 g protein per lb of bodyweight. Calculate your TDEE and eat 250 calories more than that (if you're lifting). Eat some veg with your lunch as well. Add stuff like quark or cottage cheese to your meals for easy cheap protein. Here's a sample of my bulking diet as an example. Mind you, I'm tall, lift 4 times a week and ride my bike to work, so your needs may be different from mine:

Breakfast: a lb of full fat quark and a muffin with a cup of coffee
Lunch: 4 slices of whole wheat with PB, a pint of whole milk, a salad and a piece of fruit
Dinner: whatever I fancy, with at LEAST a cup of veg and 1/3 lb of meat
Before bed: another lb of quark

This puts me close to 4000 calories and 200 g of protein. Drop the muffin and go for low fat dairy and you can significantly drop the amount of calories while maintaining a high amount of protein.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69247309
E=mc2 bro
The "calories" given for uranium in OP is just the energy - > matter equation for 1 gram of matter
E is energy in joules
m is matter in kilograms (1 gram = 0.001kg)
c is the speed of light in meters per second (299,772, 458)

So the energy in 1 gram of uranium, or splenda, or fat, or protein, or iron, or gold, is
0.001 * (299,772,458 * 299,772,458)
This gives us 89,863,526,600,000 joules.
1 joule is 0.000239kcal
89,863,526,600,000 *0.000239 = 21,477,898,326.96kcal

So there are actually 21 billion kcal in 1gram of matter.

The 18-20 million kcal figure given for uranium specifically refers to the energy released if it goes through full alpha decay, but that's much less fun to calculate

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
If you're skinny, don't worry deeply about what foods you're consuming as long as it is not complete junk 100% of the time. You're in need of calorie count and large amounts of protein more than anything. If you're fat, cut out the junk and eat below your average calorie count. That's probably the easiest blanket statement I've been able to come up with considering food when it comes to people. Skinny people need more big people need less if their goal is the opposite of where they're currently sitting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
Dieting has the most amount of broscience/mommybloggers, misinformation, misleading studies by supplement companies or product pushers, as well as just a general lack of nutritional education from public education. It literally takes years to unlearn a lot of the complete horseshit that people have been taught.

Weight loss is going to be highly personalized for each person because, well, we're all built a little different. But the general truths hold up; CICO is king and there are no exceptions. Anyone saying otherwise is bending the truth or trying to hide it behind something misleading.

For example, a lot of people proclaim keto as the best fat loss diet, without needing to cut out fat from the diet. but at the end of the day, the weight loss comes mostly from calorie restriction, not some magic ketosis.

If you count your calories and are consistent, you will be able to manage your weight without issue.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69250035
Simplest way is this: Google "Gravitus lifting calculator" and input your measurements in there. It'll spit out estimations of how much carbs, fat, and protein your body needs, and how many calories to consume to lose X lbs a week.

That's it, just put together a diet that meets those requirements. You must hit your protein and fats goal, and use carbs to fill in the calorie gap, or cut carbs if you're going over your limit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
>Some say skipping breakfast is good, some say it's bad.
Skipping breakfast reduces calorie intake, but also makes you hungrier later. It’s just another way of doing intermittent fasting.
>Some say you should cut off all fat, sugar, carbs some say you shouldn't.
Carbs are fine, added sugar and added fat is not. If you eat whole foods that have some sugar or fat in them naturally, you probably won’t be fat.
>Some recommend fasting, some say you should eat more frequently.
Fasting is fine as long as you eat at least once a day.
>Some say cheating and eating bad food in moderation is okay, some say it isn't.
It depends on your personality. Some people are addicted and can’t have any, some people can eat one cookie a day and not have anything else bad.
>Some say you just need to eat less calories than you burn, some say that doesn't work.
You need to eat less, eat protein, and eat nutritious food.
>Some say you should lose weight slowly, some say you should do it faster.
1-2 lb a week is fine.
>Some say you should try this diet, some say this one.
Join the fruit, vegetable, and lean meat cult. We have delicious salads here.

I’ve been doing full body workouts like this.

A
Deadlift
Bench
Skullcrushers
Lat raises
Row
Rear felt fly

B
Squat
OHP
Pec fly
Shrugs
Pullups
Preacher curls

3 sets of about 10 reps for everything except the deadlift and squats.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You need to ‘link’ going to the gym with another activity. So it would look something like: go to the gym when coming home from him/work.
Personally I’m allowed to work from home 3 days per week, so I lift in my home gym during my lunch break these three days. In my brain : working from home = lifting.
I was never consistent in going to the gym because I didn’t have one near my home or work. So for me the solution was embracing my laziness and investing in a home gym.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69253905
Have a program with deloads and mesocycles like Renaissance Periodization or a just definitive months long program. My consistency skyrocketed when I had a program designed to manage all the variables:
>systemic fatigue
Your body requires rest and if you are laser focused for a time and pushing too hard, you'll burn out and give up
>tracked progress
Seeing progress is way different than remembering progress. You see how much your lifting is progressing by numbers and stats. Recalling your progress is a much softer punch, you are mostly just feeling like you're doing the same thing without an exact appreciation of how far you've come. I have all my progress saved, to be able to go back and say damn

Also, your stints are 2-3 months at most..that's not enough to motivate yourself by visual change. Visual change is the *KEY* motivator early on. My first two years were great on this, because I was skinny fat. I was 18% bodyfat, after 3 months I saw some back development and thought "whoa" this actually works. 3 months later I saw chest coming in. After that, delts! and then legs! And on and on. THEN, I cut for the first time, and boom I got abs. I did maintenance and then cut again, and boom veins, vascularity everywhere and defined muscle all over. All these cycles, not really maintenance, gave something new visually. It just builds on top of each other and becomes real. You can ONLY expect these noticeable changes after 3 months, and you have to continue with a plan to keep it going. Hope this helps. You need a strong why and go hard purely on faith at first, but once you get visual changes they keep you going

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69249589
I fried chicken, fried onion and put a few asian things for flavor and sauce like söy sauce, oyster sauce, rice vinegar, ginger, garlic, sugar, chili, hoisin sauce. Also sesame seeds.
If you want to make a sauce like that, the simplest way is to mix söy sauce, sugar and either lime juice or rice vinegar until you taste and think that there's a perfect balance between salt, sweet and sour. Then when you learnt that basic feeling you can add other suitable asian things, my first recommendations would be ginger and garlic. Sesame oil is great for east asian flavor too.
Usually I make something like this but mix everything together with noodles instead of having it with rice. Putting a fried egg on top is good.

posts.com:

>>69247290
These are steps I took which greatly improved my sleep:
>remove all caffeine and stimulants
Completely cut it out, not even in the morning. Caffeine/stimulants inhibit melatonin production so low melatonin producers can have sleep ruined even by a morning coffee.
>go to bed at the same time every night
>wake up at the same time every morning
This helps your body develop a consistent rhythm so you can get tired at the right time each night and be hormonally prepared for sleep.
>walk outside for ~20 minutes in the sun shortly after waking up
This kickstarts melatonin production. Contrary to what most people think, melatonin is produced slowly all day long and not just before bed time, so it's important to get full spectrum sunlight in your eyes to tell your body to get started on it.

If you do these things you'll set yourself up for much more consistent and deep sleep. You're waking up all the time because your body's hormonal cycles are out of whack.

Mineral sunscreens are your best friend as they are 100% non-toxic, non-absorbing, and non-estrogenic; they're just zinc or titanium dioxide. I found a really good korean brand that sells a mineral-only sunscreen that both absorbs somewhat and is tinted so it's practically unnoticeable. Barring that, wearing a bucket hat and long-sleeved light shirts will go a long way. Luckily bucket hats are somewhat fashionable again at the moment, and sports companies like adidas and nike make good looking ones with wider brims that are both made of light materials and are vented, specifically for runners who want to keep the sun off their face but not burn up in the heat

>>69244861
You can never make a causal claim from correlational research. Causal research means you're keeping all other variables the same across treatment.

For oxybenzone, it's true that it's now a common chemical in sunscreen... but that's not all it's been used for. Benzophenones like oxybenzone have been used in industrial manufacturing for the last hundred years. We use it less now than ever. The issue is that it's a forever chemical that doesn't degrade or take itself out of the environment. Why are skin cancer rates up 200%? First of all, we don't. We have higher skin tumor rates, but the majority of skin tumors are benign. The reason why they're higher is probably because we screen for skin cancer a lot more than we used to.

>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
Prognosis can be affected by the type of genetic mutation that the person with CLL has.[78] Some examples of genetic mutations and their prognoses are: mutations in the IGHV region are associated with a median overall survival (OS) of more than 20–25 years, while no mutations in this region is associated with a median OS of 8–10 years; deletion of chromosome 13q is associated with a median OS of 17 years; and trisomy of chromosome 12, as well as deletion of chromosome 11q, is associated with a median OS of 9–11 years.[79] While prognosis is highly variable and dependent on various factors including these mutations, the average 5-year relative survival is 86.1%.[80] Telomere length has been suggested to be a valuable prognostic indicator of survival.[81] In addition, a person's sex has been found to have an impact on CLL prognosis and treatment efficacy. More specifically, females have been found to survive longer (without disease progression) than males, when treated with certain medications.[82]

>>69252929
if you want to fully stretch your distal hip flexors, you go into a bulgarian split squat stance on a chair. If you want to fully stretch both your distal and proximal hip flexors, you go on a table or bed, fully extend the hip and peform a side bend to also get your QL with your proximal psoas. Her stretch is made ineffective by over extending the hips, preventing the posterior pelvic tilt that is necessary for proper hip flexor stretching and she isn't getting any bang for her buck by also initiating a combat stretch on the contralateral ankle / achilles tendon.

I know more than you on this topic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69253087
when muscles stiffen they don't relax. What happens to a chronically overused muscle? It both shortens and weakens. Stretching is good for fixing postural imbalances especially if those imbalances are caused by daily life, like sitting on a chair for hours a day and then going to bed and laying on your side in a fetal position, further flexing the hip even more.

You may be confusing stiffness with things like bracing. There are two ideologies on this, Mckenzie and McGill, both have demonstrable results. Mckenzie is more focused on stretching and mobility and McGill focuses more on bracing and power.

There's much less variance in Germany (and Europe in general). The school was ~top 3 in Germany for my field. In (Anglo/Germanic/Scandinavian) Europe, any reasonable state school will probably confer a reasonable comprehensive and non-bullshit education. In the US, the bottom-tier is a joke and the top-tier shits on the rest of the world. Part of the issue in the US is that everyone goes to university, even people who really shouldn't and are too dumb, and that dumbs down the experience and level. At top US schools, your peers are all from the top ~10th percentile, and so the level is immediately higher. That makes a big difference. In Europe they're also happy to fail you and introductory courses in non-bullshit STEM majors often have drop-out rates as high as 50%.
The standards in Germany were high, but the pedagogy and quality were a meme. One of the reasons people associate German engineers with competence is because the system is self-selecting: only the good, self-sufficient students make it through their shitty education.

posts.name: Are amino acids calorie free?
posts.com:
I tried to research online but get mixed answers, some say they don't have calories (and can be ingested during a fast), and some say they do have calories, the same amount as protein, just doesn't have to be disclosed on nutrition label bc of FDA requirements, so companies opt to deceiving display them as "no calorie", when in actuality they do.

What is the truth my fitness bros? Thanks!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69252634
Every gram of protein/amino acid is going to contain 4 calories no matter what amino or what the source is. Some (BCAA for example) have a greater effect on insulin, and this just looks like another overpriced BCAA product.
Is the amount in a serving too small to cause a reaction and break a fast? Who can say? Definitely has the potential to though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69252695
Also wanted to add that your muscle mass will be fine, especially if you are only doing something like IF or OMAD and still training regularly. Having periods of fasting (even extended ones) is more natural to human evolution than being sedentary and grazing all day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69252634
There are only 22 amino acids to bring about in combination for a single protein.
All proteins will have the same number of amino acids, but not the same amount of individual amino acids.
So when someone says 1g of protein, they really mean at the heart of the problem one gram of amino acid.

>>69250663
The rest of the protein is absorbed, just more slowly than when cooked, and the beneficial nutrients in the yolk are highly heat sensitive (particularly the cholesterol which quickly oxidizes and degrades).
>Heating Has No Effect on the Net Protein Utilisation from Egg Whites in Rats: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5346405/
>Digestibility of Cooked and Raw Egg Protein in Humans as Assessed by Stable Isotope Techniques: https://academic.oup.com/jn/article/128/10/1716/4723080?login=false
In that second study, if you look at the graphs you'll notice that the cooked egg whites cause bigger spikes earlier on that drop off heavily while the raw egg whites have a lower overall value that's sustained much longer. So the protein is still all being absorbed but over a longer period of time, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

It's about $6 for a dozen, pretty typical price. Check out your local farmer's markets and/or have a look on sites like localharvest.org to see what's near you.

>>69250954
>how is that efficient in any way?
It's less efficient but they only sell locally so that doesn't really matter like it would for some huge corporate operation. The Amish generally aren't after Infinite Growth (tm) in the first place like your average corporate capitalist and will even downsize their businesses if they become too successful. Maximum efficiency isn't necessary.
>why would someone do this?
Because they care about the welfare of their animals, it improves the quality and nutrition of the eggs, and eggs from chickens raised like this fetch a higher price.
>what about the male chicks culled at birth?
They're raised for meat and live with the hens until that time. The eggs are often fertilized but they're collected before any development can occur (fertilized eggs only develop embryos if they're kept at an appropriate temperature for long enough, keep them below 100F and they'll never develop even if fertilized). It's pretty much how chickens always were raised before the era of factory farming.
